channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Day, a Life: When a Medic Was Killed in Gaza, Was It an Accident?
item.media:description: Rouzan al-Najjar, 20, was killed by an Israeli sniper on June 1 while she was treating the wounded at protests at the Gaza border.
item.description: When an Israeli soldier killed Rouzan al-Najjar, Palestinians called her an innocent martyr. Israel portrayed her as a threat. The truth is more complicated.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Bangladesh Elections: Choice of ‘Lesser of Two Evils,’ Voters Say
item.media:description: Hanging electoral fliers ahead of the 11th general election in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has fostered booming economic growth and better social development. But voters are wary of her authoritarian tendencies.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Congo Votes, Amid Ebola Crisis and Problems at Polls, After Years’ Delay
item.media:description: Elections in the Democratic Republic of Congo, delayed by two years and a week, finally took place on Sunday in most of the country.
item.description: The long-delayed vote to replace Congo’s leader of 18 years, Joseph Kabila, was marred by torrential rains, lost voter rolls and malfunctioning machines.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Hello. Does Poland Have Vampires? My Date Wants to Know My Blood Type.
item.media:description: One man requested that the British Foreign Office speak to a massage parlor in Bangkok on his behalf: He had fallen asleep during a massage and felt he should not have to pay for it.
item.description: The British Foreign Office released a list of the oddest phone calls it received this year from Britons abroad.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Moscow Dispatch: Stalin’s Soaring Moscow Towers Sorely Need Body Work
item.media:description: The Moscow State University building, at nearly 800 feet, is the biggest of the so-called “Stalin high-rises” that were built to symbolize the Soviet Union’s victory over Nazi Germany and which transformed Moscow’s skyline.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The massive “Stalin high-rises,” built to embody the victorious spirit of postwar Russia, still offer some of the best apartments in Moscow, but are now badly decayed.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: China Thwarts U.S. Effort to Promote American Culture on Campuses
item.description: The Chinese authorities blocked activities of centers run by American universities and financed by the State Department. After 10 years, none are left.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and LUZ DING

item.title: Romania, Fighting the E.U., Prepares to Lead It at ‘Crucial Moment’
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Bucharest celebrated the corruption conviction of the governing party leader in June.
item.description: The government has turned to Euroskeptic rhetoric to defend its stance on anticorruption legislation, even as it is scheduled to take its turn in the presidency of the bloc as Brexit looms.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Colombia Investigates a Possible Plot to Assassinate President, Official Says
item.media:description: President Ivan Duque of Colombia in Bogota this month. The foreign minister said Colombia’s intelligence services had been hearing chatter about alleged plans to kill Mr. Duque.
item.description: Foreign Minister Carlos Holmes offered few details in a video address Saturday night, but said several Venezuelans had been arrested recently with assault weapons.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hungary Sheltered a Fugitive Prime Minister. Did It Help Him Escape?
item.media:description: Nikola Gruevski, Macedonia’s former prime minister, arriving at a courthouse in Skopje, Macedonia, last January.
item.description: After a former Macedonian prime minister jumped bail and ended up in Hungary, the far-right Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, was accused of helping him escape.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Gay Couples Rush to Wed Before Brazil’s New President Takes Office
item.media:description: Two women before a group wedding ceremony in São Paulo, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.description: The incoming president, Jair Bolsonaro, has promised to end same-sex marriage, leading to a surge in the number of gay weddings before his inauguration.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: China to Retry Canadian on Drug Charge Amid Diplomatic Spat
item.media:description: The Canadian Embassy in Beijing. Relations between China and Canada have deteriorated sharply in the past month.
item.description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg appealed against his jail sentence in a previously obscure case. He now faces a retrial that could impose a death penalty.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Shehu Shagari, Former Nigerian President, Dies at 93
item.media:description: Former President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria had been a schoolteacher raised as a devout Sunni Muslim. He sometimes seemed an unlikely figurehead for a nation that projected itself as Africa’s colossus.
item.description: Mr. Shagari sought to revive democratic rule, but military officers deposed him during a 1983 economic crisis caused by plummeting oil prices.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Egypt Kills 40 Suspected Militants After Deadly Bombing of Tour Bus
item.media:description: Three Vietnamese tourists and an Egyptian guide were killed and at least 10 others injured when a roadside bomb hit their tour bus on Friday, less than 2.5 miles from the Giza pyramids.
item.description: Security forces raided sites in North Sinai and Giza, the Interior Ministry said on Saturday, a day after a bomb killed three Vietnamese tourists and their Egyptian guide.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMED EZZ

item.title: Inside Facebook’s Secret Rulebook for Global Political Speech
item.media:description: Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: Under fire for stirring up distrust and violence, the social network has vowed to police its users. But leaked documents raise serious questions about its approach.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Empty Homes and Protests: China’s Property Market Strains the World
item.media:description: The Yudong International apartment complex in Jurong, China. Sales surged in Jurong after a housing boom in nearby Nanjing. Now many apartments sit empty.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: A glut of unwanted apartments gets part of the blame for a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy. In some places, homeowners are taking to the streets.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and CAO LI

item.title: Times Insider: How Times Reporters Froze a Fatal Moment on a Protest Field in Gaza
item.media:description: Times reporters Iyad Abuheweila, left, and David M. Halbfinger interviewed Eslam al-Najjar, a volunteer medic who worked with Rouzan al-Najjar in Khuzaa.
item.description: A volunteer medic was killed by Israeli gunfire on June 1. Times reporters combined a forensic visual investigation with on-the-ground reporting to reconstruct what happened and tell her story.
item.dc:creator: MALACHY BROWNE

item.title: An Israeli Soldier Killed a Medic in Gaza. We Investigated the Fatal Shot.
item.description: On June 1, an Israeli soldier shot into a crowd, killing a volunteer medic named Rouzan al-Najjar. Israeli officials say soldiers only use live fire as a last resort. Our investigation shows otherwise. We analyzed over 1,000 photos and videos, froze the fatal moment in a 3-D model of the protest, and interviewed more than 30 witnesses and I.D.F. commanders to reveal how Rouzan was killed.

item.title: Son of Yemeni Mother Dies Soon After She Won Visa Battle With U.S. to See Him
item.media:description: Shaima Swileh holding her 2-year-old son, Abdullah Hassan, at the U.C.S.F. Benioff Children’s Hospital in Oakland, Calif.
item.media:credit: Council on American-Islamic Relations, via Associated Press
item.description: Shaima Swileh, a Yemeni citizen who lives in Egypt, fought to visit her only child in California, where he was receiving treatment for a brain disease.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: British Design for D-Day Stamp Gets Address Wrong by 8,000 Miles
item.media:description: A stamp design that was to be issued in 2019 to mark the 75th anniversary of the D-Day landings. The Royal Mail has apologized because the image showed American troops in Asia.
item.description: A commemorative stamp for the 75th anniversary of the D-Day landings showed American troops on a beach in Asia, instead of Normandy.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Chinese Scientist Who Claimed to Make Genetically Edited Babies Is Kept Under Guard
item.media:description: Dr. He at a conference in Hong Kong in November. Scientists there denounced the work that he claimed to have carried out.
item.description: He Jiankui, who was last seen in public in November soon after his stunning announcement, is sequestered in a guesthouse in the city of Shenzhen.
item.dc:creator: ELSIE CHEN and PAUL MOZUR
item.category: Southern University of Science and Technology

item.title: Louis Rudd Completes His Trek Across Antarctica 2 Days Behind Colin O’Brady
item.description: O’Brady and Rudd, a captain in the British Army, are the first people to cross Antarctica from coast to coast solo and unassisted.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SKOLNICK

item.title: Shutdown, E.P.A., Syria: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Guatemala Cautious on Young Migrants’ Deaths, Wary of Angering U.S.
item.media:description: The funeral of Jakelin Caal Maquín last week in her home village of San Antonio Secortez, Guatemala.
item.description: Guatemalan officials’ courting of the Trump administration may explain their muted response to the deaths of two children in U.S. custody.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: El Chapo Trial Shows That Mexico’s Corruption Is Even Worse Than You Think
item.media:description: In two months of testimony in the trial of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the drug lord known as El Chapo, nearly every level of the Mexican government has been depicted as being on the take.
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.description: Nearly every level of the Mexican government has been depicted as being on the take. Officials in Colombia have also been portrayed as deeply corrupt.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER

item.title: On the Front Line of the Saudi War in Yemen: Child Soldiers From Darfur
item.media:description: A Sudanese militiaman fighting under the command of the United Arab Emirates along the coastal highway leading to the contested port of Hudaydah, Yemen.
item.description: Led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the Saudis have used their oil wealth to outsource the war, primarily by hiring desperate survivors of Sudan’s conflict.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Human Rights Advocate Under Fire in Case of Arab Princess Who Claimed Abduction
item.media:description: The daughter of Dubai’s ruler, Latifa bint Mohammed al-Makhtoum, with Mary Robinson, a well-known human rights advocate, in a photo released by Dubai.
item.media:credit: United Arab Emirates News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Mary Robinson, a former United Nations human rights commissioner, has been accused of covering for Dubai’s mistreatment of a daughter of the ruling sheikh.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Clinton Envy, Mandela and a Horse: Glimpses From the U.K. Archives
item.media:description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain and President Bill Clinton meeting with schoolchildren on their way to 10 Downing Street in London in 1995.
item.description: Notes, memos and diplomatic cables detailing the workings of the British state were released from the National Archives.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Showmanship, and Conflict, as Darts Goes From Smoky Pubs to TV Spectacle
item.media:description: At times, a dart match can seem more like a rowdy frat party than a sporting event. Here, fans celebrate during the World Championship at the Alexandra Palace in London this month.
item.description: The yelps and fist pumps and prancing around stage are already irritating some traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Bomb in Egypt Strikes Bus Full of Vietnamese Tourists, Killing 4
item.media:description: The scene of an attack on a tourist bus on Friday in Giza, south of the Egyptian capital, Cairo.
item.description: Ten people were injured and three Vietnamese tourists and an Egyptian tour guide were killed when a bomb blast hit their bus near the famous pyramids of Giza.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMED EZZ

item.title: Students Defiant as Chinese University Cracks Down on Young Communists
item.media:description: Students demonstrated Friday in Beijing against a change in leadership of a Marxist group at Peking University.
item.description: In a rare rebuke, Peking University students denounced officials for blocking a student-led campaign for workers’ rights that has embarrassed the government.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Hungarians Fume as Statue of Former Leader Is Downgraded
item.media:description: The statue of Imre Nagy, the leader of the 1956 Hungarian uprising, stood next to Parliament in Budapest.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Imre Nagy, the communist prime minister executed for rebelling against the Soviet Union, is a hero to many in Hungary — but not to its far-right government.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN NOVAK

item.title: ‘That’s Shiny’: How a U.K. Plane Spotter Cracked the Secret of Trump’s Iraq Visit
item.media:description: President Trump arriving at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland after visiting Iraq. A British aviation enthusiast spotted the unannounced outward flight from his kitchen window.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: An aviation enthusiast saw something shiny out of his kitchen window. Public data, and a community of online sleuths, did the rest.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SCHAVERIEN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: He Helped Indonesia Through a ‘Year of Disasters,’ While Facing His Own
item.media:description: Sutopo Purwo Nugroho, the spokesman for Indonesia’s disaster management agency, has Stage 4 lung cancer. He said he “accepted that it was my fate, just like people who were affected by earthquakes and the tsunami.”
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Sutopo Purwo Nugroho, a government spokesman, has kept the public informed about earthquakes, landslides and tsunamis while being treated for Stage 4 lung cancer.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Amos Oz, Israeli Author and Peace Advocate, Dies at 79
item.media:description: The Israeli writer Amos Oz in 2016. He was known for his deeply observed fiction and liberal politics.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: One of Israel’s most prolific writers, he published numerous works of both fiction and nonfiction, and his writing was translated into more than 35 languages.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Syria’s Kurds, Feeling Betrayed by the U.S., Ask Assad Government for Protection
item.media:description: Turkish-backed Syrian fighters gathered in the area of Sajur near Manbij, Syria, on Friday.
item.description: Other powers in Syria have begun positioning themselves to take advantage of the vacuum left by a U.S. withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: gender letter: 2018: Year of the Woman, in 5 Powerful Quotes
item.description: The stories that defined this year for women around the world.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: North Korean Defectors’ Personal Data Was Stolen by Hackers, South Says
item.media:description: A North Korean defector on the South Korean side of the border in September.
item.description: The names, birth dates and addresses of 997 defectors were stolen through a computer infected with malicious software, the South Korean Unification Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: China’s State Media Finds Good News in Underwear
item.media:description: Workers checking steel bars at a factory in Liaoning, a rust-belt province that has posted some of China’s worst economic results.
item.description: An unorthodox economic indicator points to an improving outlook in China’s rust belt. Economists are skeptical, but there are precedents for this kind of measurement.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and CAO LI

item.title: Shutdown, New York Sky, ‘Bandersnatch’: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Sunrise at the U.S. Capitol on Thursday. Parts of the federal government remain dark.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Afghanistan Dispatch: Along a Road of Sorrow, a Toddler Lost Her Name, Her Family and Her Life
item.media:description: Mullah Jan, a distant relative of the toddler, holding her body wrapped in a white shroud while waiting outside the hospital where she died.
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.description: A roadside bomb wiped out a family in Afghanistan, except for a tiny girl who arrived in a shepherd’s arms at a hospital where no one knew her name. She was called “Angel” as she struggled to survive.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Germany, Facebook, Saudi Arabia: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: The Capitol on day six of the government shutdown.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Angered at Trump’s Visit, Some Iraqi Lawmakers Want U.S. Troops Out
item.media:description: President Trump during his visit to Al Asad Air Base in Iraq. He spoke on the phone with Iraq’s prime minister, Adel Abdul Mahdi, but did not meet him in person.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: A range of Iraqi politicians criticized President Trump over his surprise visit as an affront. The most strident critics were affiliated with Moktada al-Sadr, a nationalist Shiite cleric.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Germany’s Far Right Rebrands: Friendlier Face, Same Doctrine
item.media:description: Members of Generation Identity, a far-right youth group, at their headquarters in Halle, Germany.
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.description: A far-right youth movement is part of a growing network of actors giving extremism a friendly face — and worrying intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Amazon Sees in Brazil Continent-Size Profits and Problems
item.media:description: An Amazon logo in São Paulo, Brazil, a country where complicated taxes, high import costs and difficult roads pose problems for the company.
item.description: The retail behemoth is laying the groundwork to penetrate Brazil’s huge consumer market, analysts say. Success won’t come easy.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: 5 Takeaways From Facebook’s Leaked Moderation Documents
item.media:description: Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
item.description: The New York Times obtained more than a thousand pages of internal guidelines. They shed light on how Facebook decides what should be kept off the platform.
item.dc:creator: AODHAN BEIRNE

item.title: Shutdown, Markets, Facebook: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and ELIJAH WALKER

item.title: As Congo Election Nears, Rioters Storm an Ebola Center and Unrest Grows
item.media:description: Police officers used tear gas Thursday against demonstrators protesting the delay of elections in Beni, Congo.
item.description: Delays of long-anticipated elections to replace President Joseph Kabila are adding to insecurity in a region plagued by an Ebola outbreak and militia violence.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Suicide Bombing Kills Pakistani Insurgent Wanted for Attack on Chinese
item.media:description: The Chinese Consulate in Karachi after an attack in November. The man suspected of planning that assault was killed Tuesday by a suicide bomber.
item.description: Aslam Baluch, who officials say masterminded last month’s attack on a Chinese consulate in Pakistan, was targeted in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH, MUJIB MASHAL and ZIA ur-REHMAN
